quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: Advanced Force Problems and Synthesis (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Complex Applications and Multi-Step Force Problems

questions.question: A force of 100 N gives object A acceleration of 4 m/s². The same force gives object B acceleration of 2 m/s². Which has more mass?
questions.explanation: m = F/a. Object B: 100 N / 2 m/s² = 50 kg. Object A: 100 N / 4 m/s² = 25 kg. Object B has more mass.

questions.question: Why is it harder to push a full shopping cart than an empty one?
questions.explanation: The full cart has more mass and thus more inertia, resisting changes to its motion.

questions.question: A rocket in deep space fires its engines, producing 50,000 N of thrust. If its mass is 10,000 kg, what is its acceleration?
What is the net force on a 2 kg object that is accelerating at 3 m/s²?
questions.explanation: F = ma = 2 kg × 3 m/s² = 6 N.

questions.question: If an object's mass is halved while net force remains constant, what happens to acceleration?
questions.explanation: a = F/m, so if m is halved, acceleration doubles.

questions.question: What is the mass of an object that weighs 196 N on Earth? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
A car going around a curve at constant speed is:
questions.explanation: Changing direction requires acceleration, even if speed is constant.

questions.question: A 0.2 kg baseball is thrown with 40 N of force. What is its acceleration?
Which statement about force and motion is correct?
questions.explanation: Net force causes acceleration (change in velocity), not velocity itself.

questions.question: A 1,500 kg car accelerates from 0 to 27 m/s (60 mph) in 8 seconds. What is the average net force?
A 10 kg box is pulled across a frictionless surface with a force of 30 N at a 30° angle above horizontal. What is the horizontal component of the force?
questions.explanation: Horizontal component = F × cos(30°) = 30 N × 0.866 ≈ 26 N.

questions.question: If an object is moving with constant speed in a vertical circle, what can be said about the net force?
questions.explanation: In circular motion, even at constant speed, the direction of acceleration (and thus net force) is constantly changing toward the center.

questions.question: A 1000 kg elevator accelerates upward at 2 m/s². What is the tension in the cable? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Tension must overcome weight AND provide upward acceleration: T = mg + ma = 1000(9.8 + 2) = 11,800 N.

questions.question: Two forces, 8 N east and 6 N north, act on a 2 kg object. What is the magnitude of its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Net force = √(8² + 6²) = 10 N. Acceleration = F/m = 10 N / 2 kg = 5 m/s².

questions.question: A 50 kg object on Earth is taken to a planet where it weighs 400 N. What is the gravitational acceleration on that planet?
questions.explanation: g = W/m = 400 N / 50 kg = 8 m/s².

questions.question: A 5 kg block and a 10 kg block are pushed with the same net force. The ratio of their accelerations (5kg:10kg) is:
questions.explanation: a = F/m, so if F is constant, acceleration is inversely proportional to mass. 5 kg block has twice the acceleration of 10 kg block.

questions.question: A car's engine produces 4000 N of force. If 1000 N is used to overcome friction and air resistance, what net force accelerates the 800 kg car?
questions.explanation: Net force = engine force - opposing forces = 4000 N - 1000 N = 3000 N.

questions.question: An object experiences three forces: 12 N north, 5 N west, and 12 N south. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: North and south cancel (12 N - 12 N = 0), leaving only 5 N west.

questions.question: A 2 kg object initially at rest experiences a constant net force of 6 N for 3 seconds. How far does it travel?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 6 N / 2 kg = 3 m/s². Distance = ½at² = ½ × 3 × 3² = 13.5 m.

questions.question: What is the weight of a 70 kg astronaut on the Moon, where g = 1.6 m/s²?
questions.explanation: Weight = mg = 70 kg × 1.6 m/s² = 112 N.

scoreMessages.90: Exceptional! You have mastered complex force problems and multi-step applications.
scoreMessages.70: Excellent work! You handle advanced concepts well; review vector components and circular motion.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundation. Focus on practicing multi-step problems and force component analysis.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Review Newton's Laws and work on breaking down complex force scenarios.
